data.text:
@bethsawin you're probably not. these folks did a solid analysis of it recently (as always)
https://t.co/Rko5Izh17r
@bethsawin Well, you're not alone. I noticed the same thing and switched to getting local data from my state public health website this week. Not sure what's going on

@bethsawin Not sure what data our state is reporting anyhow--they're cutting back on testing. Wish everyone did sewage surveillance, reported at least weekly. That seems like a decently leading indicator.
@bethsawin Note at the top of that page https://t.co/BeknMyZGVf
@bethsawin This page looks to be up to date (the "old" risk levels) https://t.co/4ZJAbcFbUS
.@luckytran hoping you can explain what I might have missed....

Otherwise when you see a green county it might mean it was green a week ago, using an indicator that is biased to lag "new cases" by a couple weeks. Like looking into outer space, and seeing only history, but thinking you see events as they are happening.
Just yikes, unless I'm confused (which I hope is the case).

Or are we trying to steer a dynamic system by updating data with about the same time constant as the doubling time of the problem? Because that's not a good idea, especially not when the metric is most sensitive to lagging indicators (hospitalizations).
